channel.title: Whitehall Mennonite Church's Podcast
channel.itunes:subtitle: To be the people of God, Inviting others to know Him.
channel.itunes:author: Whitehall Mennonite Church

item.title: Surprised by the Spirit
item.description:
Scripture: Acts 2:1-21 (Pastor Rose Bender)

Pentecost Sunday

The Holy Spirit brings us new life.

Come Holy Spirit breathe new life into our relationships, into our marriages, into our families, into our congregations, into our cities. Come breathe your new life, restore and recreate.Teach us to be your people to love as you love to forgive as you hve forgiven and to be a community where your will is done as it is in heaven. It was a surprising gift that day, a gift of new life.
item.dc:creator: Whitehall Mennonite Church

Come Holy Spirit breathe new life into our relationships, into our marriages, into our families, into our congregations, into our cities. Come breathe your new life, restore and recreate.Teach us to be your people to love as you love to forgive as you hve forgiven and to be a community where your will is done as it is in heaven. It was a surprising gift that day, a gift of new life.

item.title: Ascension Day
item.description:
Scripture: Acts 1: 1-14 (Pastor Rose Bender)

The truth of the ascension is a very important part in helping us understand that Jesus does indeed have the power now to make all things new because of his position. All things are under his authority. He is the one that will make all things new. It is because of Jesus' coming to earth, His life, His teaching, His healing, His death, His overcoming death, His being raised to glory that we can trust that the soverign reign that has begun and is complete in heaven will one day be complete for us on earth.

item.title: Making all things new
item.description:
Scripture: Isaiah 65: 17; Rev 21: 1-6 (Pastor Rose Bender)

"See, I will create new heavens and a new earth. The former things will not be remembered, nor will they come to mind. But be glad and rejoice forever in what I will create, for I will create Jerusalem to be a delight and its people a joy." (Isaiah 65:17,18)

Isaiah paints a picture of the way things will be. This is also to encourage us to live differently in the present. Its an orientation of how we are to live right now.
Where are you allowing the dream of God to impact your imagination. How does the dream of God affects where you live, how you work, what you buy... how does it impact you?

How does the dream of God affects where you live, how you work, what you buy... how does it impact you?

item.title: New eyes
item.description:
Scripture: Acts 9:1-20 (John Connolly)

Where is God at work in your life? How do you remove the scales from your eyes and receive the light? How do you get rid of the burdens you are carrying? What distractions do I need to put aside to pay attention? Maybe we need to give ourselves a little break from all the "stuff" that are distracting us.

item.title: Experiencing the Risen Lord
item.description:
Scripture: Luke 24: 36-49 (Pastor Rose Bender)

The people walking in darkness
  have seen a great light;
on those living in the land of deep darkness
  a light has dawned. (Isaiah 9:2)

This is the hope of the resurrection and this is what happens when we experience the risen Lord. So let this be our prayer and let this be our hope.

item.title: Participating in New Creation
item.description:
Scripture: 1 Corinthians 12; Ephesians 4 (Emily Ralph)

We are the body of Jesus together and as the body of the resurrected Christ we have a job together. We are not passively waiting for Jesus to return but just as Jesus extended his arms to the forgotten and the oppressed, the resurected body of Jesus creates space for healing for belonging and for freedom.

item.title: Bearing Witness
item.description:
Scripture: Luke 24: 1-12 (Pastor Rose Bender)

The women who had been with Jesus bore witness to the empty tomb. The angel said... Why do you seek the living one amongst the dead. He is not here. He is Risen!!! 

Christ is risen indeed!!!

item.title: On the Way to Jerusalem
item.description:
Scripture: Luke 13: 22-33 (Pastor Rose Bender)

Jesus was ministering up north in Galilee from where he travelled south towards Jerusalem, towards the holy city where the temple was, towards what would become (as we know) his death.

Jesus went through the towns and villages, teaching as he made his way to Jerusalem.

While on his journey Jesus was still helping people but he had a focus and a purpose, he was on a misson from God and he was not distracted by the all the good things he was doing to help people on the way.

item.title: Spring House Cleaning
item.description:
Scripture: Luke 11: 14-28 (Scott Brooks Cope)


The house needs to be cleaned but it cannot be kept empty after it is cleaned. When was the last time you cleaned your house and filled it with friends and neighbors and said come and rejoice because God loves me and he loves you and he loves us all, so I want to get together to celebrate that.


Keeping our spiritual house clean is important but what keeps it filled? Here are 4 things that should fill it: -

  1. Remember how much we are loved by God.A daily reminder of God's love that saves & heals us.
  2. Daily Prayer. An intimate way of connecting with God.
  3. Reading the word of God: Starting the day by reading the good news before reading the bad news.
  4. Go and help others keep clean.

Keeping our spiritual house clean is important but what keeps it filled? Here are 4 things that should fill it: -
Remember how much we are loved by God.A daily reminder of God's love that saves & heals us. Daily Prayer. An intimate way of connecting with God. Reading the word of God: Starting the day by reading the good news before reading the bad news. Go and help others keep clean.

item.title: One made whole
item.description:
Scripture: Luke 8: 26-39 (Pastor Rose Bender)

Radical change and transformation can happen when Jesus is allowed, when we invite him to impose God's order on the chaos that is around us. We can be like the town's people in this text and be ignorant of who Jesus is, or, we can be open and ready and available and say God here are the places of chaos, places of woundedness in me  an ask for his healing and wholeness.

item.title: Seeing with New Eyes
item.description:
Scripture: Luke 7: 36-50 (Urbane Byler)

We are challenged to practice looking beyond the obvious where God's grace is at work in changing lives, in chaning our lives, in making it possible for us to take risks to be vulnerable, in changing the way we see other people as people who are not perfect but people who by God's grace are children of God.

item.title: Are you the One?
item.description:
Scripture: Luke 7: 11-23 (Pastor Rose Bender)

Did John expect a certain kind of Messaiah? He sends his disciples to Jesus to ask if He was the Messaiah? Can someone who pays more attention to the dead the poor the outcast the lawbreaker and the diseased, be the real Messaiah? John most likely did not doubt that Jesus was the Messaiah but he wanted to confirm if this is how the kindgdom of God will look like.

The reign of God is here. The anointing that was on Jesus is on us. We are the ones people look to, to see if this is the real deal. What are others seeing and hearing about us? If Jesus is truly our center, shouldn't we be pointing them to also believe that Jesus is the one and they dont have to wait anymore because he has come.

The reign of God is here. The anointing that was on Jesus is on us. We are the ones people look to, to see if this is the real deal. What are others seeing and hearing about us? item.title: Costly Discipleship
item.description:
Scripture: Luke 6: 17-38 (Pastor Rose Bender)

What does following Jesus looks like?

True discipleship will be more costly than we expect. But God's abundant blessings will be more than we can imagine.

Is this a cup I can drink?

item.title: Power, Prayer, Parties
item.description:
Scripture Luke 5: 12-39 (Rob Epinger)

The text has 3 stories: 

-Jesus heals a man with Leprosy

-Jesus forgives and heals a paralysed man

-Jesus eats with sinners

The key verse that is being focused in this message is v16 "Jesus often withdrew to lonely places and prayed."
item.dc:creator: Whitehall Mennonite Church

item.title: God's work of Reclaiming & Restoring
item.description:
Scripture: Luke 4:31-44 (Naveen Singh)

This text portrayed Jesus reasserting God’s right to rule in a creation that had rejected that rule.

43 But he said, “I must proclaim the good news of the kingdom of God to the other towns also, because that is why I was sent.”

This kingdom of God is not referring to somewhere up in the sky, or something we experience only after death. Rather, it is God’s reign or rule on earth, a reign that would continue into eternity.

The establishment of God’s kingdom on earth brings reconciliation between people and God, and extends that reconciliation throughout the world.

Hatred and injustice are replaced by the love and justice of God.

Sickness and death are consumed by God’s wholeness and eternal life.

Human rebellion against God’s reign is replaced by loving obedience.

Rather, it is God’s reign or rule on earth, a reign that would continue into eternity. The establishment of God’s kingdom on earth brings reconciliation between people and God, and extends that reconciliation throughout the world. Hatred and injustice are replaced by the love and justice of God. Sickness and death are consumed by God’s wholeness and eternal life. Human rebellion against God’s reign is replaced by loving obedience.

item.title: Loved by God and Led by the Spirit
item.description:
Scripture: Luke 3: 21-22; 4:1-15 (Pastor Rose Bender)

From now through Easter—our theme is “Moving towards Jesus as our center” (key verse 1 Cor 3:11). 

11 For no one can lay any foundation other than the one already laid, which is Jesus Christ.

We will be using a study of the Gospel of Luke to do this and also some texts from the book of Hebrews.  The Luke texts emphasize Jesus’ humanity.  The Hebrews texts remind us of Jesus’ divinity.

item.title: Epiphany: Illuminating the World
item.description:
Scripture: Psalm 72:1-7, 10-14 (Pastor Rose Bender)

Today we remember the Magi's -- those astrologers who were seeking and questioning. They were willing to leave their comfortable world and travel to worlds unknown. Drawn by the star, also drawn by a divine curiosity that God put within them. They wanted to know about this king. 
We also celebrate Epiphany: The coming of the light -- the light that reveals truth.

item.title: A Flood of Reversal - My water just broke
item.description:
Scripture: 1 Samuel 1:24 - 2:10 (Angela Moyer)

Looking at God’s upside down kingdom that Jesus brought to earth, who raises the humble and hungry and lowers the proud and mighty.

Are you ready to receive from God who turns our world upside down?

Will we remain faithful to God, the One who is always faithful to us?

item.title: Refined by Fire
item.description:
Scripture: Malachi 3:1-4 (Pastor Rose Bender)

“Flood of Mercy” is our theme for Advent. The theme is about how God comforts and disturbs, two ideas that are hard to hold together. We know what it’s like to be flooded with joy and excitement, overwhelmed by God’s love. We also know that sometimes flood carry away and destroy things that matter. The image of a flood fits well with this season, which at the same time calls us to repentance and invites us into new life. 

Malachi asks -- Who can endure the day of his coming? Who can stand when he appears? For he will be like a refiner’s fire or a launderer’s soap. He does not sugar coat what it means to be invited into new life but in His tender mercy God purifies us through the refiner's fire and destroys the impurities.
item.dc:creator: Whitehall Mennonite Church

item.title: What is that in your hand?
item.description:
Scripture: Exodus 4: 1-17 (Donella Clemens)

What is that in your hand?

The scripture text from Exodus 4 has a number of excuses that Moses makes to God explaining why he is not the right choice. I guess most of us can relate to these excuses.

It is not about the miracles but the seemingly ordinary things that we already have in our hands. Because it is not about us but what God can do through us when we trust in His wisdom. God has made us special & unique and we can all play a unique role in the building of His kingdom.

item.title: Stewardship - Q&A
item.description:
Scripture: Matthew 6:19-34; Luke 6:38 (Pastor Rose Bender)

Our hard stewardship questions

  1. How to prepare responsibly for retirement?
  2. How can we be accountable to each other with regard to finances?
  3. How do you pick and choose charities?
  4. If I give and am still able to make a savings, should I feel guilty? How much should I give?
  5. Is saving money for retirement/rainy day really biblical? Or is it just a part of our Swiss/German heritage?  What about Jesus’ parable of the man who built ‘bigger barns?’
  6. How can we stop giving at 10% when there are so                      many with so little? 40%? 80%? Are we instead responsible for stopping just short of being a burden on society?
  7. 10% before or after taxes? (could be a 30% difference)
  8. Can we talk about our choices of money? How do we             create space for honest conversation? Would be useful, humbling, maybe encouraging to hear what people do with what they have…would like to talk about mutual aid as well.
Giving…to whom? How much?
a. 10% of your net income to the church and any extra you have to charities of your choosing.
b. Take care of all my bills and needs--then whatever I have left can go to the church.
c. Give to whatever appeals to my sympathy/emotions at the time.
Not how much of my money will I give to God,
but how much of God’s money will I keep for myself?
--John Wesley

Saving…how much? Planning for retirement? 

a. Give 10%, save 10%, live off 80%
b. Save, invest, and save some more.  You have to be prepared.
c. Instant gratification is the name of the game—you can’t take it with you, so why save?
Do not store up for yourselves treasures on earth,
where moths and vermin destroy,
and where thieves break in and steal.
But store up for yourselves
treasures in heaven….
for where your treasure is,
there your heart will be also. 
Accountability…who do we talk to about how to spend our money?
a. My money, my business
b. If I start talking about it, people will judge me. 
c. That’s what financial planners are paid to do.

• Do you accept the Word of God as guide and authority for your life?
• Are you willing to give and receive counsel in the congregation?
• Are you ready to participate in the mission of the church?
item.dc:creator: Whitehall Mennonite Church
item.itunes:subtitle: Scripture: Matthew 6:19-34; Luke 6:38 (Pastor Rose Bender) Our hard stewardship questions ...

item.title: The Grace of Giving
item.description:
Scripture: 2 Corinthians 8: 1-15 (Pastor Rose Bender)

Money is not mentioned in this scripture text, it talks about giving. Grace is mentioned 10 times.

Verse 9 says ...so that you through his poverty might become rich.

Why should we give?

• Giving is a ministry that we have been given by God
• To keep our commitments
• Mutual care
• Gift of Jesus to us
• For the Glory of God

 

How should we give?

• Generously—out of our abundance
• Proportionally—according to what we have been given
• Sacrificially—beyond our own power
• Voluntarily
• Systematically
• Cheerfully/joyfully
item.dc:creator: Whitehall Mennonite Church
item.itunes:subtitle: Scripture: 2 Corinthians 8: 1-15 (Pastor Rose Bender) Money is not mentioned in this scripture t...

item.title: The Kingdom of God – the Economy of God
item.description:
Scripture: 1 Timothy 6:6-21 (Pastor Tom Albright)

"Having" is fun but "Being" takes a lot of work. The scripture says Godliness with contentment is great gain.

Focusing on what brings "Life"? 

The goose, the golden egg, or new life? Just wanting to collect all golden eggs and storing them up is a trap but nurturing the golden egg to life is what we are called to.

Just wanting to collect all golden eggs and storing them up is a trap but nurturing the golden egg to life is what we are called to.

item.title: Putting our money where our mouth is
item.description:
Scripture: Deuteronomy 26:1-15 (Pastor Rose Bender)

This text is a declaration by God's people: -

1. (v3) God's promise has been fulfilled & acknowledged.

2. (v5-10) Testimony of God's salvation.

3. (v13) Keeping the promise we have made.

All we are given is not for us alone.

The earth is the Lord’s, and everything in it, the world, and all who live in it; -Psalm 24:1

item.title: Colossians 4
item.description:
Scripture: Colossians 4: 2-6  (John Connolly)

Devote yourselves to prayer, being watchful and thankful.

  And pray for us, too,

  that God may open a door for our message,

  so that we may proclaim the mystery of Christ, for which I am in chains.

  Pray that I may proclaim it clearly, as I should.

 

Be wise in the way you act toward outsiders;

  make the most of every opportunity.

Let your conversation be always full of grace,

  seasoned with salt,

  so that you may know how to answer everyone.
item.dc:creator: Whitehall Mennonite Church

Let your conversation be always full of grace,   seasoned with salt,   so that you may know how to answer everyone.

item.title: A Contrast Community
item.description:
Scripture:  Colossians 3:12-17 (Pastor Rose Bender)

We are called to live differently.

Colossians 3

12 Therefore, as God’s chosen people, holy and dearly loved, clothe yourselves with compassion, kindness, humility, gentleness and patience. 13 Bear with each other and forgive one another if any of you has a grievance against someone. Forgive as the Lord forgave you. 14 And over all these virtues put on love, which binds them all together in perfect unity.
